Comments_List: I learned mainly about the development of racism and how people of color are at an unfair disadvantage in cities around the world. We started with a historical look the first half of the course and ended with a what's happening in the world now look with topics such as gentrification and environmental justice.

This definitely counts as one of those famous perspective-altering classes. The way I look at urban centers has completely changed, and I'm able to analyze what I see much more critically and connect these observations to the effects of historical and contemporary discrimination.
I learned how to do field studies and how to engage with course readings to build proper arguments.
It's a really great intro to urban studies course, and I learned a lot about the way race/class/gender interacts with physical spaces, both historically and currently.

I better understand the structural factors that contribute to racial, class, and gendered inequality in American cities and their surrounding metropolitan areas. I also rode a New Haven city bus for the first time. I also thought about the role of private capital in gentrification for the first time.
This class really helped me to understand the modern day inequalities that exist in larger American cities. It also helped me decide on what I would like to possibly major in.

I learned so much more not only about the process of cities and the roles of people within them--both in terms of people with incredible amounts of power within cities as well as often marginalized and underprivileged citizens who were more likely to suffer from the laws and principles put into place by the people in power in these cities. Through the field projects, I learned so much more about how to interpret my understandings and notice every day concepts like gentrification in my community, both New Haven and at home, and I also overall gained a greater understanding of concepts of inequality within cities than I had before.

Learned about systemic oppression in cities, but also about the agency of the oppressed peoples. That dual emphasis was the most fascinating part of the course for me. The course is in two partsthe first half focuses on American urban history, and the second part focuses on current issues facing cities. Seeing the history lead into the current issues was great; I really like the design of the course. I also began to learn about spatialization/urban studies, something I definitely want to learn more about at Yale.
I learned to be more aware of my surroundings while walking around New Haven. Racial and socio-economic disparity, gentrification

I learned about the different inequalities that people face in cities, especially low-income communities of color. I really enjoy the lectures on gentrification, because they taught me things that I never knew about my home, Brooklyn.

this course helped me learn a lot about the historical processes that have created the city as we know it today and helped give me the vocabulary to talk about space in ways that I hadn't been able to before.
How to read sociological theory
How to look at issues in american cities that affect different groups of people and why this is historically.

Expanded knowledge of how cities came to be based on earlier historical processes. Taught me to consider how structural institutions contribute towards inequality in race, class, and gender. Learned why people of color and women are disproportionately low income and subject to worse conditions in cities.
It made me more aware of the issues currently in our cities and how they came to be through historical processes

I feel like I gained a greater insight into the processes perpetuating inequality in American cities. I think the course successfully identified high level, easily understandable factors contributing to inequality concerning race, class, and gender.
This class gave me a better perspective and understanding of the history behind the development of American Cities and the peoples who are marginalized by that history.
This class focused on how histories of racial segregation, suburbanization, and other urban processes of the past shape the issues that exist in society today.

Learned a lot about structural inequalities in cities and how they were/are constructed and maintained, e.g. through transit inequality, discriminatory housing practices, suburbanization, and gentrification. Learned a lot, too, about New Haven through the field projects, which I really enjoyed.

This course is a good introduction to the socially created inequalities in the US. At times it was dry and prof Barraclough would say some fufu white people shit, but she means well. It's also deceptively a lot of writing, so be careful. Also, she should make it clearer that the take home final is actually a final paper, don't be deceptive.

I gained a deeper understanding of various contemporary urban issues to do with race, gender, and class inequality--I now can identify instances in which these issues are relevant and have the vocabulary and historical knowledge to talk about them in a meaningful way.

This course tries to frame modern urban issues of race and class in the context of historical routes. However, I think the lectures, readings, and assignments execute this objective poorly. Having completed this course, I do recognize certain processes and power structures in New Haven and in my home community that I did not before -- but the course provided little to no discussion of how to think about these issues beyond identification. Put more simply, I feel like this course taught vocabulary, but not substance. Course readings were often narrow and anecdotal, offering not broad, scholarly arguments about the social processes we were supposed to be studying but instead giving personal accounts of small aspects of certain urban issues. Paired with odd field assignments that required students to jump to hasty conclusions about the efficacy of public transit after spending just 30 minutes riding a bus, the readings and the course at large lacked any balanced, comprehensive, empirical arguments to back the material on the syllabus. This was disappointing.
Amazing course. You really learn about how urban history has contributed to the racial, class, and gender inequality we see today.
I learned how to talk about and analyze lived experience from an academic standpoint, and I learned how to read physical locations/environments as primary sources.
So much. I learned a lot about urban history and contemporary urban issues.

I learned how to critically analyze our nations urban history and how that has shaped the social constructions of race, class, and gender in our society today. I learned about the evolution of our country's relationship with business and public space, from learning about the industrialization era and Fordism to gentrification today.

I gained a lot of insight into the different processes and issues present in New Haven today. I learned a lot from completing the field projects and thought it was really useful to have that hands-on experience.

This course was a real eye-opener. From the field projects, I saw that if I just opened my eyes, I could visually see everything discussed in class in the landscape of New Haven. The applicability of the knowledge made this class exciting and rewarding.

Pretty crazy how much you can learn in one class. I learnt so much about historical processes that have been inequalities in race, class and gender in america. Hopefully i will not only be more interesting at dinner parties but i will be aware when i am in a position to do/contribute something positive.

This course was incredibly eye-opening, and probably one of the best classes I have taken at Yale. I truly look at urban centers -- or just American inequality in general -- in a whole new way. Loved it.
historical and contemporary inequalities in urban spaces.

This course taught me how to analyze the history of inequality effectively even if I have not experienced many of the inequalities. I learned how to structure essays in a caring way while being analytical and strong in an argument.
The course enlightens students on the discriminations that pervade everyday life, and have become so naturalized in America.

I gained a better understanding of historical processes underlying urban inequalities. Examples of topics: role of bilingual-biracial people in navigating Detroit's early fur-trade, housing discrimination in US cities during 1900s, etc.

This course was extremely interesting to take, given current events and the political atmosphere right now. I gained a much greater insight into the historical and daily struggles of people you don't interact with every day on the street.

I learned an incredible amount about the history, social processes, and spatial constructs that have shaped race, class, and gender relations and inequalities in American cities. I came into the class not knowing much about the forces that have transformed and defined cities in the last two centuries, and I walked away knowing a lot more about the cultural attitudes and intent behind decisions made by governments, corporations, and individuals.

It's like a review of U.S. history since slavery, with more focus industrialization, urban renewal, neoliberalism, and various practices of housing discrimination. I definitely learned new things, but everything felt intuitive.

I learned about the history of race, class, and gender in cities in American and understand how historic legacies of discrimination manifest in the contemporary built environment. I think I also gained the language to be able to talk about social issues and understand better the historic context of many urban issues.

As a survey course, it is super informative about the creation of whiteness and systems of oppression in the United States. Specific histories that this course elaborated on were urban renewal and discriminatory lending.

An insight that overarches through the class is the compounding effects of history on contemporary lives.

This class provided a very formative understanding of the importance of space and how we infuse emotion, power, and control over societal constructions of space, especially in very dense urban environments when many different types of people are in contact.
I learned how to think about race, class, and gender relations in contemporary and historical American cities.
I learned the spatial and systematic ways through which people of color have been disadvantaged for many years.
Interesting history and its relation to current urban issues. I wouldn't say that I developed any knew skills but the material was interesting.
I can give you a bunch of examples of racism in Detroit and explain to you how parking lots can be symptoms of gentrification

I learned a lot of basic AMST concepts that will guide me through the major going forward. I learned to think critically about the city as I walk through it every day. I learned to look at housing, employment, public space, etc with a greater sense of history and context.

This class educated me on the entrenched policies, social implications, literature, and laws that have created and deepened the racism in American cities. This class was incredibly instrumental in my understanding of the division, inequalities, and inequity that exists today.
A historical and contemporary understanding of issues regarding race, class, and gender in American cities
I gained a broad understanding of the historical roots of discrimination in US cities, and the main problems affecting cities today.

I learned about the history of urban inequalities, and contemporary urban inequalities. I was able to observe and thinking critically about contemporary urban inequalities, and think about solutions. I became a better informed citizen.

This course got me very interested in the stories of the communities we "studied". I feel like it's extremely easy to look at statistics and research about various underserved communities, but one will not begin to understand the complexities of individual experiences until one intentionally communicates with members of that community. In other words this course was helpful in showing students the importance of valuing humanity and not just the statistics.
Pretty much all I gained from this class was slightly heightened awareness of my surroundings in a city.
Excellent class!

I developed a basic understanding of our society's structure. Much of it I kind of knew intuitively but learning the actual processes and systems was really valuable and made me think of things in different ways.

I learned MANY things about American cities, public policy, group culture, and discrimination. I had never realized that discrimination could manifest itself in physical built space, but this course really opened my mind.
I gained a better understanding of race and class inequalities in cities throughout America and how they have derived over time.
I didnt really learn anything new in this class but it definitely provided me with background and language for these topics
This class definitely opened up my eyes to the injustice going within major cities across the United States.

I learned about historical processes and practices that contributed to present-day urban inequalities. Through the 3 field projects, I developed my ability to write argumentative essays relating my own observations of the real world to class themes.
This class wasn't the most intellectually stimulating but I am now able to talk about things I observe in urban environments with a little more sophistication.
I learned a lot about cities in the united states and why they face many of the problems they do today.

I learned to view the urban landscape in a unique way. I found the course especially relevant and exciting as the content related itself back to local New Haven. I felt like I had many opportunities to apply what I learned through field projects and papers.

- Was shown the historical foundations for inequality in American cities, with a focus on the geographic distribution of inequality (not just wealth inequality) and how it came about

- Got some experience doing observational field research in a sociological / anthropological style

- Got to see and study parts of New Haven I otherwise wouldn't have
I learned how to write historical papers in a different format than I was used to.

The main focus of the class is to tease out the way contemporary urban processes and issues manifest as the products of history. The class starts with a historical account of state-sanctioned and extralegal discrimination in housing, immigration, urban planning, employment, and transit throughout the 20th century. This is I think the strongest part of the course, and should be required learning for every student at Yale in understanding why our cities and society have the inequalities that we witness every day. Professor Barraclough and her teaching team then link those histories of inequality with their contemporary consequences. I will never look at the built environment in the same way. Eye-opening and crucial learning. There's good reason why this class is one of the largest taught in Yale College.
Greater awareness of the urban issues of race, class, and gender inequality and the historical processes that created them

I learned how to truly think about space and the what the decisions about space, such as that in American cities, says about how parts of society creates inequality among different peoples. I've never been so aware and inquisitive about where I'm from, where I'm going, or where I am, as it relates to other people's quality of life.

While I have always known that the present day inequalities that plague this nation are a product of this nation's history, this course shed light on the many layers and complexities of such inequalities. Moreover, this course taught me that breaking through legal barriers does not necessarily result in any social or economic changes.
I learned about the systems of oppression within American cities and how these have affected the ways in which space has been used as well as the communities within this space.
This class provided a great new lens/context through which to examine New Haven and other American cities.
inequalities in urban environments, policies to mitigate them
This course provided a survey of historical and contemporary U.S. urban planning and policy issues.
This was a very eye-opening course with material that I think is important for all students to experience, no matter what race, class, or gender they are.

This course offered a survey of historical and modern issues relating to race, class, gender, and American cities. For instance, we covered topics ranging from housing discrimination, eminent domain, urban planning, environmental justice, to neoliberalism.
How to assess gentrification in neighborhoods, how to trace the history of deindustrialization and how racist policies that have affected communities of color for many years.

This course allowed me to developed an intimate understanding of the ways in which race, class and gender are not only social constructs but also spatial constructs that have played integral roles to the development of urban spaces across America.

I learned how to write college level essays without guidane (no rough drafts, just a prompt and feedback on the final draft). I live in Philly and the class has given me a new lens and understanding of the current state of the city.
I learned more about trends that I knew were happening in the US but didnt know the historical contexts for.
how to read the space I live and interact in.

This course was amazing. This class helped me to critically evaluate details of US cities that prove unequal. Walking down the street is a completely different experience for me after taking this class.
A new way of thinking about space and the history of American cities - so important for everyone to take!!
This class gave me an incredible new lens with which to view American society. I find my daily life changed by the curriculum Professor Barraclough gave us this past semester.

I learned about elements of a city that I had not considered prior to taking the class. I know look at the city I live in in a different manner and can have an actual dialogue about it due to the gift of vocabulary to describe it.

In this amazing course, I learned so much about the history of American cities and the roots of nearly every contemporary problem cities are facing today. These insights are applicable to every urban environment in this country.

I learned a lot about the history of race, class, and gender through the framework of the city and learned more in depth how the city was used as a tool for discrimination, as well as progress in America.

I have become more aware of how race, class, and gender affect most aspects of our lives, especially in historical contexts. This course has taught me to look past the surface of certain ideas/concepts and focus on what they mean and the impact they have on people's lives.
Application of historical trends to contemporary issues; reading academic papers about urban studies; applying outside material to an original argument; doing field work and making observations
Connecting historical practices to current issues in equality in urban settings
Developed a greater understanding of the city I am from and also New Haven... A wonderful course that all Yale undergrads should take regardless of their majors or academic interests.

I developed a deep understanding of the historical and present circumstances that brought about the socioeconomic inequality and urban risks that are faced by the poor and minority communities in the American city.
I learned a lot about the different things that have formed and continue to shape cities. I further developed my writing skills and my knowledge about cities.
I really enjoyed learning a basic history and overview of American Urbanization. I find that I didn't learn or improve any skill set which was disappointing.
I was able to obtain a solid basis on many different topics regarding cities in the US and how different ideologies of the past relate to current issues.
I never analyzed urban studies so it was very interesting to gain a new perspective.
Insight into the historical foundations of modern day cities, and insight into New Haven and modern day phenomena that occur.
I learned to look at the world differently, and to see past instances of racism that I have seen in my life.
A decent intro into some urban studies issues while allowing you to explore New Haven. Writing assignments, however, were not very helpful, as they were broad and inconsistent across TAs.

The class is great for allowing you to understand historical processes and how they dictate current realities. You'll know some of the material intuitively, but Professor Barraclough will build a structure around those disparate thoughts and really allow for you to understand the sociological processes pretty well. There's also a lot she'll introduce to you the for the first time, or even alter your perception of some topics. Great class!

I learned a lot about how todays issues that many people of color face are a direct result of historical housing practices. I learned more about how many issues that people of color face, like finding a job or better housing, is mainly due to many injustices they face.
I learned about the historical factors that created the current system of racial and gender inequality in America.

Professor Barraclough constructs a class that is able to explain systematic oppression in a way that few other classes can. By grounding it in the exploration of the city, she is able to track how racism and white privilege is an active system that creates lasting and life threatening results.

In this course, I learned how to understand historical processes and apply them to the modern day. This helped me consider many contemporary issues and inequalities using a historical lens. I was also able to practice art analysis, and even do some ethnographic work in the city of New Haven.
This course gave me a broad understanding of inequality in the United States and how economic processes in cities are deeply entrenched in racism, classism, and sexism
I learned about the recurring production of race, class and gender inequality in America throughout history.
Good course to get a sense of some of the spatial biases that have formed over the course of American history.

Social and cultural phenomena thats affecting cities, past and present: gentrification, transportation, environmental concerns, employment & labor. Take it! Easy and relevant concepts, no prior experience necessary to do very well.
the historical social patterns along lines of race, class and gender that led to modern social patterns, policies and habits we see in American cities today

I learned how the vast number of historic processes of segregation based on race, class, and gender continue to contribute to the systemic inequalities present in American cities and how that severely limits the possibilities of economic and social growth and stability in marginalized communities.
I learned about the history and policies underlying systemic injustice, primarily racism, in America, with a focus on cities.

I gained a broad understanding of some issues in urban studies that disproportionately affect people of marginalized groups, with focus in: historical context, city structure, housing inequity, transportation inequity, environmental racism, etc.

I gained a greater understanding of the specific systematic ways racism has been carried out in cities. The class definitely gave me better insight into things like gentrification, housing policies, and environmental racism.

This course was extremely informative about the historic trends shaping cities and urban spaces throughout American history, particularly the sections on neoliberalism and gentrification. I've learned to synthesize and compare my in-class readings to write informative papers on real-world issues.
I learned all about the deliberate processes that have shaped American cities and caused/exacerbated inequities according to race, class, and gender.

The field assignments that were designed to get us out into New Haven, outside the Yale bubble, felt like we were still examining the city from an "other" point of view. It emphasized that we were not a part of it and that the people living in it (outside of Yale students) are people to be studied.
I felt like the class delt with really important issues but from a very elementary level which made it hard or me to engage.

This was a fantastic course. The lectures were always engaging, the material was interesting and relevant, and the workload was quite reasonable in my opinion. I always enjoyed coming to class. Professor Barraclough is an excellent instructor who was also very receptive to student concerns and advice.

Strengths: lectures are very engaging, and the course is very user-friendly (lectures are posted online if you miss a class, readings are complementary to the lecture and not redundant). The midterm and final structure are so helpful. 

Weaknesses: I felt that all three field projects could be improved. The first field project centered more about artistic analysis than it did about the course material, and especially as the first project, I felt like there were probably better ways to engage with what we were learning. 
For the second one, I think it is worth considering the issue of a large amount of Yale students descending on the bus system in order to analyze the habits of normal people in New Haven. It felt very invasive and insensitive. Additionally, there was some language in the assignment itself that was questionable (specifically when we were instructed to "Analyze the demographic profile of the passengers inside the bus and at the bus stops. Consider
their age, sex, ethnicity/race, and apparent socio-economic status." I felt like we were ending up completely stereotyping in order to prove our point). I really enjoyed writing the paper, but the research I did to get there felt like I was exploiting people's daily lives and struggles for a grade. 
For the third one, as someone very new to New Haven, I wished I had more insight on the city in order to complete this project. Since the assignment was given over Thanksgiving break, I wish we would have been given the option to write about our hometown.

Everyone has something to learn from this course, and the sense of inclusivity that Professor Barraclough fostered here was greatly appreciated.

I did not get the chance to attend either film screening, but I did watch both films. Perhaps more time in between the screening and its direct relevance to the course would help.

My only concern with this class is that I felt like lectures and readings were sometimes repetitive because lectures often summarized the findings of the readings but didn't always expand upon or challenge those findings in any significant ways.

The strengths of the class were certainly the material--I learned so much and Professor Barraclough was an amazing professor who had an incredible amount of insight about the topics she was discussing, and I think that the Field Projects were a unique way of getting students to consider concepts of inequality and what they might mean around them, and interpret them through firsthand experience. Sometimes the prompts for these projects, however, were incredibly broad which made it hard to know what questions should be answered in the project. And, the second Field Project made me feel a little uncomfortable because, even though I understand the purpose was to observe transit inequity in person, I thought the whole observation process was a little strange since we were supposed to be observing people going about their everyday lives in a way that made me feel a little weird.

Strengths: 
Perfect amount of reading, and great readings (about 50-70 easy pages a week): not too much, but enough to feel like I learned a lot every week.

Professor Barraclough is phenomenal: her lectures are incredibly engaging. The 50 minutes passed so quickly every time. 

Weaknesses: 
The filmsthere were two """"mandatory"""" film screeningsdid not fit into the course as effectively as they could have. Instead of doing the first paper on a piece of art, which is academically confusing, since this class does not talk about art at all all, we should do a reflection on a film in connection to the readings. 

The food and water section at the end felt a little thrown in: I would appreciate more discussion about food and water in the history section so the current section feels more grounded. 

My section all agreed that we wanted to follow up about Native Americans in the "current events" side of the coursewe started with discussions of them, but then did not revisit them. 

The "gender" section of the class was lackingit often felt somewhat thrown in. The class could either be changed to "race and class in American cities," and keep the same amount of gender stuff, or should include more feminist theory, history, and current movements to balance out the gender aspect. Also, one reading about queer urbanism would be nice.
The lectures were good but at times felt a mile wide and inch deep. I wish we spent more time talking about how race plays into healthcare access.
The strength is Professor Barraclough and my TA Joey's dedication to teaching. The weakness is that there is not enough time to talk about the weekly readings in only one section.

The field projects were awesome! Getting to go out into New Haven and take the bus or identify gentrification was a great way to apply the theories we had learned in class to the realities of city life which was awesome to be able to do!

This course does not push its students. The readings were uninteresting and had very little to do with the lecture material. The only time we ever worked with the text was in papers, and even that was very infrequent. Section should have been about the readings, but so few students did the readings that section became useless.
Moreover, the class failed to be an intellectual space. Instead of discussing theory or readings, we simply spoke of anecdotes or experiences that we have had. While recognizing the importance of lived experience, this class took it too far in that it became difficult to even talk about the theory because certain students wanted to hear themselves talk about their lives.
Lectures are amazing and readings are relevant

Professor Barraclough is an engaging lecturer and there are interesting readings. The midterm is structured well, however I found some of the field projects and the final paper to be a bit vague and pointless. Also what you get out of of the course is largely based on how good and engaging your TA and mine personally was not great
strength was very informative, weakness was readings were SUPER long

This was definitely an interesting course, and I enjoyed going to lecture. However, I feel like the assignments did not do a good job stimulating thought outside of what was covered in lecture. The assignments were my least favorite part of the class - they weren't "hard", but they were so uninteresting and structured that it was a pain to get through each one. While the assignments required observation of real-world processes, the instructions and guidelines for what to write about were so strict that leaving campus was not able to do much to inspire your writing.

I think that the assignments weren't great, especially field assignment 1. I thought the lectures were excellent but they often talked about certain specific cases and ranged across a variety of cities, never giving a comprehensive history of the specific cities talked about.

Strengths include Professor Barraclough's teaching and clear passion for the topic, as well as the sections as opportunities for students to discuss, for instance, their experiences growing up as members of different communities and cities across the country.

Main weakness is that the class sometimes felt less like an academic setting and more like a gathering of "woke" students trying to show that they were more knowledgable about and sympathetic to the plights of the urban poor than you were. This was especially true in section and often went unchecked by the TA.

Also, I was very disappointed by the format of the "final exam." First of all, it was a final paper, not a final exam. Don't even call it a "take home exam" when it is literally just a final paper. Take-home exams typically do involve writing an essay of some form, but are usually administered with time restrictions. I was extremely frustrated to learn that I would have to write an actual, 10-page final paper that would eat into the rest of my reading week.

Second, and related to the final paper, I thought the prompt was extremely unimaginative and limiting. After everything we had learned in the class, it would have been so fulfilling to be able to write about a particular urban issue, perhaps specific to a city that we cared about, and to be able to do some outside research. Being limited to the in-class readings made the paper feel like busy work, a regurgitation of what we had already discussed in class and in sections.
Prof Barraclough has crafted a good course. i'd love to see more focus on things like education and natural spaces, in the context of race/gender/class.

The class for the first half focuses on historical events/processes that shaped the contemporary issues discussed in the second half--it's great to understand how current inequalities arose, but the structure limits the number of contemporary issues that can be covered.

The course was superficial and unbalanced. Complex issues like housing discrimination and transit inequity were boiled down to sets of bullet points in lecture, presented as the totality of a subject, and rarely attempting to explore or even acknowledge the nuances of certain views on the issues. Readings never painted opposing points of view on certain sociological issues -- in fact, the readings rarely addressed the issues with clear, scholarly argument at all. Instead, the course material was a soupy mix of buzz words and political opinion. I am a liberal student extremely interested in the concepts this course seemed to offer in its syllabus, but its sheer lack of substance made it extremely difficult to engage with.

Professor Barraclough is a gem. Truly loved going to lectures. The films were not scheduled at good times, and you didn't need to watch them to do well in the class. I would recommend doing away with those.

Strengths: Field projects are extremely helpful and interesting, but don't take too much time. Lecture is interesting and well-organized, easy to take notes on. 

Weaknesses: Pace of the course varies wildly, and it was hard to tell if we were moving forward in time or just shifting around to different subject areas.

Strengths: The lectures are pretty interesting. 

Weaknesses: There are many readings, and not all of them are very accessible (as in easy to understand, they're very convenient to find). Our section was too big; I think it was about 30 people?

STRENGTHS: Professor Barraclough is a fantastic lecturer and makes class clear and interesting with personal anecdotes as well as well-selected information. The field projects were all incredibly informative and forced us to evaluate our place in New Haven and to see a different perspective of life in this city. The readings were all enjoyable and captivating while not being too overbearing. The class was a relaxed setting for discussions of race, class, and gender without feeling too forced or contrived.

WEAKNESSES: We talked about Aative American history in the beginning, but we never mentioned it again. To me that is a huge hole in our nations urban history that should have been touched upon a little bit in a modern setting. Also, the films Professor Barraclough selected for us were never really discussed in the classroom setting, so they felt pointless. Though the name of the class is Race, Class, and Gender, we didn't talk about Gender other than reproductive labor in the era of Fordism.

Strengths:
I like how integral the class was to the human experience; all of the topics we studied in class were presented with a sense of reflection on how they impact real people and their families. I was particularly wowed by a picture of an old Hispanic woman crying when she lost her mom to build Dodgers stadium. I appreciate how the class taught me about important aspects of how policies and cities contribute to disparities amongst identity constructs of Americans while still discussing how the very powers of cities that are used to oppress them can be turned around to support them.

Weaknesses:
I don't think the field projects were all that well designed. Though I enjoy that they are physically engaging with New Haven, I don't think that they are all equally helpful for long-term learning. In particular, riding the bus was a passive experience. Perhaps it would be more interesting for students to go to local libraries and partake in the education system in New Haven, or to attend a local event I like the essay regarding gentrification. I think that the final is too vague. The grading standards of creating novel ideas is absurd. We are college students (some straight out of high school); novel ideas related to the class are potentially worthy of PhDs or Master's degrees. I think that given that there is a rubric/standard for the class that is known to the TFs, why not share it with students? There is clearly a way to write an essay that the class wants and letting students blindly guess what the standards are is unfair.

Given that the class is about urban studies, it would be helpful in the final remarks of the class to contrast it to rural communities.

A strength was being able to apply the information learned in the class in scenarios which lead us to learn more about the city we occupy--New Haven. A weakness is that is sort of felt like a high school course in that the lectures were extremely broad and often times, I found myself already knowing everything that was being taught.
I found no real fault in this course. The readings were all pertinent and insightful. I looked forward to them each week. Lectures were clear and thorough.
I thought the course was great, no complaints. Even the assignments were interesting to do.

The course involved field projects based in New Haven, which were awesome though also felt a little voyeuristic at times. One weakness is the sheer size of the class -- I appreciate that Professor Barraclough did not cut anyone from the class list, so it isn't her fault, but it would've been nice to have a smaller class size.

strength: interesting enough 

weakness: just copying slides
The course was great, but it could shorten industrialization and cover more contemporary topics concerning race, migration, and refugees,

The readings were interesting. However, the class followed the powerpoint pretty closely, so I didn't always benefit a huge amount from class. A lot of the information is also intuitive if you have had history courses before. Section styles seemed to vary greatly and there was little wiggle room when it came to either switching section times or extensions. I also felt that the field assignments were somewhat superficial and would have benefited from outside research (i.e. looking up news articles about New Haven bus routes to complement our one ride).
This course was eye-opening, but it could be improved by being more than just a reading off the slides or a reiteration of the readings.

Strengths: I loved the field projects on transit equity and gentrification, which pushed me out of my comfort zone and taught me to view New Haven and Yale  and my own relationship with both  in a new light. This was a fantastic, interactive way to apply the more abstract concepts and theories we learned in class to real-life situations. The readings also supplemented lecture material well, and I enjoyed discussing them in the context of both academic theories and our personal experiences in section.

Weaknesses: I think the class focused too much on the academic discussion of inequalities and not enough on what it means for people to actually be influenced and disadvantaged by specific policies and ideologies. For example, we learned that poor women of color suffer many disadvantages from dependency on public transit, but I wanted to know how this actually played out in their day-to-day lives. For neighborhoods affected by gentrification, I wanted to hear more firsthand accounts from displaced residents, newcomers, government planners, and corporate voices. The readings helped a little with this, but overall I wish there had been more opportunities to see the real-life impacts of the laws and attitudes we explored in class. I was also disappointed in the lack of attention given to the Asian American experience, especially given that there is a long, complex history of discrimination against Asian immigration on the West Coast and gentrification in Chinatowns.

Having to go out for the field projects is valuable (inconvenient of course, but valuable). Prof. Barraclough is great. She's really considerate, and it's worth meeting with her during office hours to discuss whatever interests you.

Lectures are very engaging, and the readings are very relevant and interesting. Professor Barraclough does a wonderful job of drawing and synthesizing the main points from the readings in her lectures. However, not much of the course focused on gender in cities, so I would have wanted more readings and more of the course dedicated to gender and the intersectionality of race, class, and gender. I also sometimes found it hard to follow one issue across time because the class is so broad, i.e. it was difficult to track changes in class struggles over time because a lot of that information was presented in disjoint entities in different lectures, and because the readings were from different time periods and geographic locations. 

In section, we also talked a lot about the relationship between Yale and New Haven, and I think the course would benefit from the addition of some readings specifically about the changing relationship between Yale and New Haven over time and about "university cities," or cities dominated by a major educational institution. It would be interesting to explore this relationship formally.

The field projects are good in theory, and I understand the significance of them, but  I sometimes felt like I was treating New Haven residents and the city as "objects" of observation in order to benefit my own personal education. For instance, with the transit equity project, I felt uncomfortable observing people on the bus and taking notes and then drawing my observations from that single bus ride to talk about transit equity in all of New Haven. I'm not sure if there's a way around this, perhaps a restructuring of the prompts or just more discussion of academic practice and respecting residents' space.

The second half seemed not as strong as the first, historical half. It was not structured chronologically, which is not a bad thing; it was an awkward transition perhaps between the two modes of historiography.

Furthermore, this course is SEVERELY lacking in queer histories of urban space. Gender (and sexuality) seemed to have less emphasis in relation to the other words in the course's title. 

Finally, the course historicizes indigenous peoples in America. Focusing only on how Native peoples shaped early settlements, there was ZERO mention of termination policies, rural-urban migration patterns and the contemporary experiences of urban indigenous people.

This class provides a very empowering sense of understanding the world in a new way and using that knowledge to challenge structures that have been exclusionary or oppressive on the basis of race, class, gender, sexuality, nation, etc. I feel very grateful for taking the time to learn how these overarching historical ideas impact the very land we interact with everyday. Because this is an introductory course to urban studies and spatial understandings of environment, there was definitely a lot to cover, and I would like more concrete relations of the contemporary movements we learned about with the historical processes of conquest and colonization. I heard from some students that they did not like how Native American influence over space really stopped with historical conquest, and they would like a reintegration of these narratives that are usually forgotten in mainstream understandings of the world.

This course was structured well to connect the historical to modern issues in American cities, but I found that we often "villanized" one group of people, which made the course uncomfortable sometimes. Especially, when I was part of the group that was portrayed in a negative light. I also wish there was more on gender discussions, for that seemed to be shoved in on the end of sentences or lectures sometimes.
This course is very interesting. The lecture is easy to follow, and section really reinforces the material.

The strengths of this course would definitely be the lectures and the readings and the way my section was run. I've never had such a rich but accessible selection of readings in one course. And the lectures were so coherently structured; every single one constructs a narrative that sticks with you. I'm not sure whether to call this a weakness, but I felt ambivalent about some of the assignments. But this is probably something I should have taken up with the professor mid-semester. This course also kinda upheld a gender binary by talking exclusively about women when it came to the gender components of the course. How do these policies impact trans and gender nonconforming people? Also, there was no discussion of disability and this seems particularly important when we talk about the built environment. I think this course could stand to expand its imagination vis-a-vis the various modes of subjection it takes up.
Cool class! Loved the field trip things

Strengths - LECTURE!! GO!!! professor barraclough is incredible and engaging and her lectures are really really important to understand the class material. the assignments are both fun and interesting to complete and draw upon the text in a meaningful way.

weakness- although I loved my TA there should be more structure to sections.

The strengths is that you learn a lot from this class from the lectures, readings, field projects, and discussion sections. The weaknesses include that the lectures can sometimes overgeneralize material and the field projects can feel uncomfortable when you are profiling citizens of New Haven and trying to make grandiose interpretations
Lectures are very insightful! The weakness of the course is in its broadness - its hard to learn specific information from very general themes.

The course is strong in giving a very nice summary on history of urban inequalities and contemporary urban inequalities. It could be improved by not utilizing powerpoint slides because it can distract us from the actual discussion of the topic by the professor.

Strengths: The lectures/lecture slides were very insightful. The "Field Projects" were engaging and required students to leave the "Yale Bubble" and interact with the New Haven community. The topics of study were generally very interesting.

Weaknesses: The wording of "Field Project #2" felt ostracizing to members of urban communities. It had a very "zoo exhibit" feeling where the students were asked to go in the community and observe as an outsider into a habitat that is both unfamiliar and alien. Then, the students were expected to report on how to make an aspect of the community better without having had any prior experience with the issues that members of the community face everyday.

Lecture was definitely targeted towards underclassmen, which is fine. However, it was so large that it was easy to disengage. As a matter of fact, I did-- I stopped attending lecture because I felt I wasn't learning anything at all. I stopped attending section because I didn't care enough to do the readings at some point.  Lecture slides were disappointing and even laughable. I just could not justify taking such a class, which seemed so illegitimate and a waste of time as compared with my other classes. I never thought I would be so disappointed.

While this course obviously cannot cover all city scapes and the history of different ethnic groups, I found it problematic that the only instance in which Asian-Americans or Asians in cities was discussed was in the example of ethnoburbs.This brief guest appearance, only depicted Asians as being the cause of white flight from the suburbs b/c Asian children academically competed with white children. I found this problematic as it introduced racism against Asians only within the context of model minority stereotype, honestly PERPETUATING this narrative as the presentation didn't necessarily justify whites being racist against Asians, but it present the racism as normalized, and like they had good reason to be racist due to
 the competion. As this is an introductory class on race for many, and this is THE ONLY context that  most studnets will receive on racism against Asians, this is incredibly misleading. Maybe including a something on Chinatowns? Something that gives better context on how whites and Americans have always been racist against,  Asians, BESIDES MODEL MINORITY FOR ONCE. 

Thank you for reading this, I very muc appreciate it.
Outstanding lecture content, kind and connected TAs.
The material was pretty basic which was a good foundation but also not very novel
Not nearly as much "Gender" of the three topics named in the title.

Strengths: Even though the field projects were slightly annoying and inconvenient, they were helpful in getting out into the city and actually seeing how the ideas we had learned in class manifested themselves.
Weaknesses: I felt as though much of the lectures were taught in broad generalizations and general trends about which groups were disproportionately affected by which policies. This was remedied, however, by references to specific case studies and policies.
I really liked the lectures, but felt as though some of the readings were a little unnecessary especially for the essays.
I loved the lectures and section. The content and projects are engaging.

I think its a very introductory course and that it has alot of information packed into one semester but I still think it is worth taking because it does a really good job at summarizing the main points of these structures

strengths: variety of assignments and great readings
weaknesses: lectures not necessary for course
Strengths is the interesting material of the class, and the breadth of what the class covers. Weaknesses would be the giant lecture style.

The best part of this class were that the assignments forced you to engage with the city. It was an interactive take on classwork that other courses so rarely encourage. I do think that the readings could be selected with more care and attention; I think they could more directly relate to the week's lecture and match the generality of the theme than focus on singular aspects of the issue because when it came to writing papers I found that many of those articles did not actually relate to my topic because they only focused on one issue.

The course lectures were organized really well and facilitated learning. The prompts for writing however were often confusing and very open ended which I found very frustrating and difficult to understand what was being asked of us.

Some of the strengths include the field projects. I think the format of the projects are creative and allow for an in-depth application of the course content. The weaknesses include a lack of structure in section discussions. I feel like we lost a lot of time wandering through the readings without really grasping some key important discussion topics.

Strengths: 

- Well structured, lots of the readings are pretty engaging, section is useful, assignments are clear, and the material feels important and relevant

Weaknesses:

- Sort of predictably delivered and not the most intellectually engaging course--often feels like everything you're hearing makes so much sense that you maybe already knew it

This course's strength is that it draws a parallel between U.S. history and current sociological phenomenons in a clear and concise way. It allows for great, interesting discussion sections. Its weakness is that it involves field projects that are somewhat disconcerting to complete.

My ONLY complaint in the whole course is a logistical one: PLEASE PLEASE in the future do not call a 7-10 page final paper a "take home exam" on the syllabus. 

As students shop classes at the beginning of the semester, scheduling a manageable finals period takes into account final assignments and their due dates. A final paper and a take home exam typically fit very differently into that puzzle, and it felt disingenuous to label a paper as an exam. It frankly sucked a great deal of my enjoyment out of the class at the very end of what is overall an amazing course.

If the paper is going to stay, and was always going to be a paper, let us know before the last day of class what the prompt is so students can make greater use of their time at the end of the semester and avoid dire time conflicts/constraints.
Field projects were engaging

The lectures were excellent. Incredibly formatted with clear transitions from class to class. It was a great overview of many of the different forms of inequality, but still managed to include tremendous detail.
For me, the best parts of the course were the field projects and the specific opportunities to engage with the city of New Haven.
field projects could have been more comprehensive but fewer

I think the course's readings were insightful, and I also appreciated that Professor Barraclough provided many examples or case studies in her powerpoints to show the extent to which cities are affected by certain problems in today's society. 

I would have preferred, however, if the lectures had analyzed issues in greater depth. I felt that many presentations discussed topics only on the surface and thus seemed somewhat self-explanatory. Additionally, I think this class's assignments could be improved. I liked the fact that multiple projects forced students to engage with the New Haven community, but I felt that directions for multiple projects were vague or unrefined. The final paper prompt especially was so broad that it limited students' ability to closely analyze a certain issue in a novel manner.

Strengths: Amazing material. Amazing lectures. Amazing TAs leading sections. Readings and movies were very interesting and manageable. I also loved the bus ride and gentrification field projects, as they really allowed me to apply what I had been learning and to continue that learning outside of the classroom.
 
Weaknesses: The final exam would have been much better if it was an exam similar to the midterm. Although I appreciated the flexibility of a take-home exam, it ended up being an essay that was too open-ended without much direction that took a lot of time and didn't feel like a way to prove I had learned a lot during the semester.

This is a phenomenal class! Every Yale student should take it if they can! The professor is extremely engaging and I would love to take more of her classes. The topics are very applicable to modern day urban issues. Growing up in a city, I was able to find many applications from the course material to my own life and I've always found that super exciting!

Strengths: interesting assignments, great TAs, engaging lecturer, informational readings, a lot of heads up on scheduling and assignments, well-crafted syllabus, overall a great class

Weaknesses: I can't think of any 

Suggestions: Maybe opening up more office hours.
The course's primary strength is in Professor Barraclough, whose strong and informative lectures make the class incredibly engaging and straightforward.
I loved how organized the class was. I could always count on the lecture slides to be posted online and the ease in access of finding the reading materials.

The material of this course was good but it was all taught with powerpoint which I thoughr made it more tedious and bland than it would have otherwise been. Also in my section we rarely discussed new ideas, instead we reviewed lectures and readigs which was less interesting and stimulating than talking about new concepts.

I think this class' lecture was very strong - every day was interesting, and it definitely showed with the number of students in attendance every day. I think the course could be improved by making the film screenings at more accessible times.

I thought there could be more statistics and more in-depth conversation about some topics seemed a bit surface-y at times. I also thought that we should just focus on race, since gender issues can't just be thrown in without much preface and wasn't discussed that much.
I think this class could be aided by more evaluation of current efforts to stop the damages caused by past government policies.
I thought the lecture was great, but the spacing of assignments could have been better.

The material is well prepared and presented, however I think discussions could be a little more guided with specific questions we are given before coming to section, questions we should be thinking bout while reading.
The material and lectures are very interesting but I did not enjoy the assignments.

Strengths: This course encourages you to engage with the city of New Haven and begin to comprehend the complex dynamics that define and construct a city.
Weaknesses: none.

Unfortunately, this is the sort of class where your experience is entirely dependent on the Teaching Fellow assigned to your section.  The strength of the course was primarily that the lectures were well organized and Prof. B was always willing to listen and engage with her students.

The strengths of this course are that Professor Barraclough was very involved with this course and she really cared about this class and her students. However, I wish that we were able to interact with Professor Barraclough more. Due to the lecture style, I did feel a little disconnected from her. However, the TAs for this class were great and were always eager to help.

My only complaint was that the field projects were poorly designed. I was frequently frustrated with what the assignments asked me to do; especially the transportation project. Although I understand the purpose of the assignment was to get individuals who have never ridden a bus to ride one, I was very uncomfortable with it. After attending high school in New Haven and having rode the bus frequently, I was uncomfortable with the fact that we were asked to make grand assumptions based on experiences after one ride. It felt very judgemental and elitist.
I enjoyed the readings of the class, lecture was amazing, and section was a great space for discussing many of the topics in the class.
This course was engaging but the readings became redundant.

I really enjoyed the course and the content. I wish that there were other methods of grading that were more standardized across sections, because I feel like my TA solely determined my grade and how well I did.
The course was great. I would suggest being more transparent about the take home final and just calling it an essay from the beginning.
Great readings, less great lectures (felt like we were being indoctrinated rather than informed), and poor section discussions.

Strengths: very good intro ERM class, was well-structured and taught, TAs were good

Weaknesses: far too broad, missed out on things like mass incarceration, readings were often too broad

It could be improved by having a more in-depth understanding of the gendered dynamics. It is a class that covers a breadth of topics, so going into detail about some of the more important ones, and perhaps introducing a bit of sociological theory to the class are some of the only things I could think to improve it.

I felt as though the fact that the "final" was explained as a "take home final" in the first weeks of class and then changed to a ten page paper was a little bit unfair. I am not sure if I would have taken this class knowing that in advance. I also felt as though the sections were not very open to discussion and creating conversation, but more about harping on democratic ideas and not really talking about issues from the other point of view. There was also a lot of conversation about the issues that occur in cities and not a lot about what is being done to prevent that.

The lectures for this course were super engaging and Professor Barraclough was super accessible to students! I loved the three "field projects" because they allowed us to apply what we were learning in class to actual scenarios, which was kind of the point of the course. 

For the same reason, I didn't like the take home exam paper. I felt like I was just regurgitating the lectures and I didn't learn anything or really engage with the material while writing it.
This course was very engaging. My only complaint is that the final paper was listed as a take-home final in the syllabus, which made me think it was an exam and not a 10-page paper.

The class could be more rigorous to ensure that students get to explore the topic fully. There should be more intro classes to ethnic studies so that classes like this do not have to spend time on basic material such as the fact that racism exists. The weaknesses are not a fault of the class, but of the Yale population.

I found that a strength of the course was the quality of lectures, quality of discussions, and the number of ideas we discussed. My main complaint is that we were not able to delve deeply into many ideas, and ended up skimming across the surface of many. I would have liked to see more time spent on some specific issues.

I really loved the concept of the field projects in this course and thought the lectures were very engaging and the timeline of the course was very organized. But one of the field projects required students to ride the bus and observe people while thinking about inequality in New Haven, which brought up a lot of ethical issues for me.

Sometimes, it felt that section didn't match the lectures. Professor Barraclough is an amazing and engaging lecturer, but the themes covered in the lecture didn't entirely match the material covered in section.
This course felt like it was not specific enough. It maybe could have been improved by focusing on the same themes and ideas but in a specific city rather than across the country.

Bad: Reading off presentation slides in lecture 

Good: Slides available after class! TFs are helpful. Exams fair and easy.

the class was thorough and comprehensive touching on a wide variety of very important topics and our discussions very much deepened my understanding of life in American cities; I cannot think of much of anything that I would change about the class structure

I liked the historical part of the class (the first half) better than the current-day part, probably because the modern-day section felt kind of disjointed. Also, some of the readings (ie. Walker) were fascinating, but others were dry and very difficult to get through. The field assignments-- the actual trips to the museum, the bus ride, and the trip to a site of gentrification in New Haven-- were awesome, but the related writing assignments were not really that interesting. I liked the material we learned, I thought the things talked about in lectures and in the reading were all very interesting and very important. However I really was not a fan of the assignments or "field projects". I felt like they were all the result of the instructor trying to do something ~different~, but they ended up just being mainly confusing and kind of problematic. I felt weird about observing regular people on the bus who were just trying to go about their day, and for the group essay (how the hell do you write a group essay???) we had to write a full paper about the process of gentrification occurring on a block after merely walking around the block for a couple of hours.
A little bit less required readings perhaps? But overall, Prof. Barraclough does a great job.

The lectures are so incredibly organized and the material from the lectures is very accessible. It's obvious that Professor Barraclough meticulously planned the lectures/outline of the class. The readings overlapped well with the lectures, and everything flowed together well. I enjoyed getting a historical background before diving into more recent developments/perspectives on American cities. The sections are great, and the assignments are very enlightening and helpful. The assignments certainly help you learn. Honestly, not that many weaknesses. Perhaps, the class would be improved if we DID NOT get the essay prompts ahead of time. That could make preparing a bit easier.
Yes!!! Definitely important for every student to take. I learned so much.
Yes.
I'd highly recommend this course to anyone at Yale. It's a lecture that I actively looked forward to. It's not very stressful, and yet when you look back you see just how much you've learned.
Yes! It was really fun and I got to explore New Haven and learn a lot about cities at the same time.
Yes. Go to lectures.

I enthusiastically recommend Race, Class, and Gender in American Cities. It is probably my most-enjoyed large lecture course that I have taken at Yale. The course also forced me to engage with the city of New Haven in a way that I hadn't before. I rode a bus for an assignment and looked at a city block's gentrification for another assignment. The three field projects kept you busy, but weren't hard, per se. The midterm was very fair. The final paper has a lot of moving parts, but I had very productive and transparent conversations with both Professor Barraclough and my TF about them that helped.

The course is a gut; there's no other way to put it. I would definitely recommend this to anyone interested in different societal processes and problems in the context of the American city. However, this is also perfect for anyone looking for an easy HU credit as well as a AFAM, AMST, ER&M, EVST, or SOCY major who knows they're going to have a busy semester but needs to take an interesting fourth class. It's very flexible, and the material is interesting. It has the potential to be much more, but unfortunately, for now, the way it is structured makes it easy to slack off and neglect attending lecture. In short: yes, I'd take it again, and I'd definitely recommend it! Try to pay attention, and you'll learn a lot.
YESSSS DO IT!!!
Yes

Through this course I learned far more about concepts I already knew a little about like gentrification, neoliberalism, and food deserts, but I also learned about brand new concepts that allowed me to broaden my understandings of cities and the people who operate within them.

Take this class!! Professor Barraclough is absolutely fantastic as a person and as lecturer, so  going to class every Tuesday and Thursday was very rewarding. You don't really need to do this readings, but you will get SO much more out of the class if you dothe readings are quite good so please do them!!

The way you look at cities will be changed: you will learn to see them through the lens of history and continued systemic oppression. EVERYONE should know all the material of this class, so no matter what academic field you are in, this class will reshape your viewpoint on urban life, history, and oppression. 

The three field projects get you engaged in the city of New Haven (art, transit equity, and gentrification) and are really helpful in joining academic work and what it looks like practically. 

It is a relatively easy course (3 short-ish writing assignments of 3, 4, and 5 pages, a pretty easy midterm, and a final or final paper depending on the year -- for us the final was scheduled to be on the last day, so she gave us a paper instead). Also, at least my TF was NOT a difficult grader. 

Make sure to go in and talk to Professor Barraclough just to get to know her. She is wonderful, and is super curious to hear and discuss her students' personal backgrounds in cities. We ended up having a 45 min discussion on our class backgrounds.

A soft yes. You don't have to attend the lectures after the midterm and when you do, the material is fairly interesting. Grading can be also harsh; it's one of those courses where almost everyone gets an A- or B+.
Yes, because this course teaches you something new about the society we live in without too much work load.

Do not take this. Lectures are uninteresting, and it shows in class attendance. Most of the material is incredibly basic and just follows logic. I went to every lecture, and I now question why. I took this course because 1. I was interested in the field and 2. I wanted a fifth class. I made a mistake. If all you want is an easy course, you could take it and be fine. Yes, great gateway course to American studies and interesting regardless of major.

Interesting class, especially for someone in STEM for whom this class is totally unique. I would say that this class is a good GUT/5th class in that it's not too hard but is very stimulating and interesting.

AMST 196 was a very enjoyable course, and I always looked forward to doing my reading, attending lecture, and, yes, even doing the assignments! It is a fairly easy class to do well in, especially since it is intro-level and filled with freshmen/sophomores.

Main topics include: housing discrimination, transit inequality, gentrification, public space & culture, racialized wealth gaps, and a few more. I had never taken a similar class, and found that this was a very accessible foray into Sociology/AMST classes.

Would recommend if you're a frosh who is curious about a lot of these issues. If you're a jr/sr you've probably learned a lot about these issues and might feel bored. It's a good general survey on inequality issues, not too focused on anything.

Professor Barraclough was incredibly engaging and so clearly passionate about the material. Although the beginning half of the class moved rather slowly (covering topics like slavery and indigenous history in the US that many students had learned about in other classes), the historical processes are nicely tied to contemporary urban issues discussed in the second half of the semester. If you're looking to better understand current events and issues of equality without having to spend an entire semester on one topic, then this class is for you!

No. While I am certainly interested in the sociological issues presented in this courses title, the course itself lacks nuance and substance. The lectures were soupy mixes of buzz words and political opinion, and vast majority of readings were void of any concrete, empirical argument. The assignments were frustrating, asking students to make extremely hasty and inevitably inaccurate judgments by riding the New Haven bus once and walking around a block, investigating gentrification. I entered the course wanting to gain concrete understanding of the political, economic, and historical structures behind the social issues in US cities, but I quickly realized that this course was teaching mere vocabulary-- that the issues we were being taught were presented in an overly-simplified, politically-tinted manner that did not engage any intellectual challenge. I do not write this because I disagree with the politics of the class (I dont) and I understand the merit the courses objective. Nevertheless, I was very disappointed with this class.
Highly recommend. You learn things that should be common knowledge, but aren't, and this class is SO eye-opening. Also really relevant to New Haven as a city. A must-take.
Definitely take this course! It will change the way you think about your hometown, New Haven, social organization, and social justice. Workload is reasonable and the field projects are interesting.
Yes, but don't take this class expecting it to be a gut. There's work involved!

YES. YES. 100% YES. This class taught me so much about our nation's urban history and how it relates to the social construction of race, class, and gender. The workload was incredibly manageable if you put in an ounce of effort, and the course materials and themes are so applicable to those who might feel like they have a narrow view of social dynamics of the country. I come from a sheltered suburb in New Jersey, and I now have so much more perspective on the country from taking this class.

I would recommend this course because it is extremely manageable work-load wise given that you'd probably already know all of the material being taught.The material is interesting--perhaps better suited for people who don't have extensive background on these topics and/or for people who have never taken and ERM or AFAM class before.

YES! From the very beginning, Professor Barraclough approaches cities as palimpsests. In approaching a study of cities with a historical framing, this course inherently has a nuanced view of the American city and the issues it faces today.
Yes. All the debates we are having today in America and all over the world about inequality, this course will help you be well informed on the issues that matter
Absolutely, if you are interested in rethinking how you view your home city and New Haven.
maybe, if they needed a social sciences credit
Yes, this course is a must-take because of how much one can not only learn in a lecture, but experience in the activities we take part in.
yes

This is a fairly well organized and easy-to-understand course. Grading is TA dependent, as per course for this large of a humanities class. I thought the readings were interesting and sometimes surprising, but a lot of the material about inequalities covered in lecture felt intuitive. I am not a fan of writing assignments, so the field projects and final essay were not my favorites, but it's not too bad as humanities credits go.
Yes. I think everyone should be required to take a class such as this.

I have mixed feelings about this class. On the one hand, it does a great job of explaining how race, class, and gender in American cities have been shaped by cultural attitudes, explicit policies, and historical trends. I especially liked learning about how race, class, and gender inequalities are not only social constructs, but also spatial constructs, and that these inequalities are often a result of deliberate decisions made by governments, private corporations, and individuals to disadvantage certain populations. This class changed the way I view public transportation and the organization of public spaces and public culture, and I think Ill come back to the things we learned throughout my life, especially now as I consider what it means to be a Yale student in New Haven. However, I hesitate to recommend this class for a few reasons. One, I think the class is overly ambitious and tries to cover too many things as a survey course. There were many times when I was left dissatisfied with the broad generalizations and oversimplifications we made regarding policies, ideologies, and peoples experiences. In addition, I think the class was unnecessarily stressful in some ways. The midterm was very fair, but the field project and take-home final instructions were vague, and it was hard to know what the expectations were regarding how much we were supposed to infer vs the limitations of our observations. Finally, I was disappointed that the class focused so much on abstract academic theories and not a lot on how specific policies and ideologies actually affect peoples experiences in practice. We also missed some great opportunities to tie what we learned into the current events/debates happening today, such as those related to police brutality, mass incarceration, and affirmative action. Overall, I think its important to remember that this is a survey course, which benefits someone for whom this material is new but imposes noticeable limitations on the depth of coverage.

I would recommend AFAM 196: Race, Class, Gender, and American Cities to another student because the material is important, but I do have some reservations. It's definitely a survey course, covering a broad range of material but in very little depth, which can be frustrating at times. The first half of the course discussed history from the beginning of civilization to the current day. I found it to be the more interesting part of the course because I learned about historical foundations of injustice that I had never been aware of. The second half of the course talked about modern-day issues of inequality, ranging from transit to gentrification. It was still interesting, relevant, and important, but it felt a little scattered. The focus was largely on racism, with discussion of intersections with class and gender. Professor Barraclough is a great lecturer and makes very good slides, so the lectures were the highlight of the class for me. The readings were hit or miss (probably about 50-100 pages per week) and section was a bit of a drag. The field assignments-- the actual trips to the museum, the bus ride, and the trip to a site of gentrification in New Haven-- were awesome, but the related writing assignments (three papers of 3-6 pages each + 1 final paper of 7-10 pages to be written during reading period) were not really that interesting or fulfilling. There was also a midterm exam with some short answers and an essay, but we were given terms and essay questions to prepare in advance which was nice.
